title: LEVEL 1: Modern Frontend (React)
description: Build dynamic user interfaces with components

lessons.title: 1.1 Introduction to React
lessons.content:
React is a declarative, component-based library for building user interfaces. It uses a **Virtual DOM** to efficiently update the UI.

## 1. Components
Components are the building blocks of a React app. They are JavaScript functions that return JSX.

## 2. State & Props
- **State**: Data local to a component that can change over time (`useState`).
- **Props**: Data passed from a parent component to a child.
lessons.expectedOutput: A button that increments a counter on click.

quizQuestions.text: What hook is used to manage state in a functional component?
quizQuestions.explanation: useState is the primary hook for adding local state to components.

lessons.title: 2.1 Express.js Basics
lessons.expectedOutput: A JSON response when visiting the /api/greet endpoint.

quizQuestions.text: Which method is used to send a JSON response in Express?
quizQuestions.explanation: res.json() automatically sets the Content-Type header to application/json.

title: LEVEL 3: NoSQL Databases (MongoDB)
description: Store and manage data with flexibility

lessons.title: 3.1 MongoDB & Mongoose
lessons.content:
MongoDB is a NoSQL database that stores data in JSON-like documents. Mongoose is an ODM (Object Data Modeling) library for Node.js.

## 1. Defining a Schema
```javascript
const userSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  name: String,
  email: { type: String, unique: true },
  age: Number
});
```

## 2. CRUD Operations
- **Create**: `User.create({ ... })`
- **Read**: `User.find({ ... })`
- **Update**: `User.updateOne({ ... })`
- **Delete**: `User.deleteOne({ ... })`
lessons.expectedOutput: Confirmation that data has been saved to the database.

quizQuestions.explanation: Mongoose provides a schema-based solution to model your application data.

title: LEVEL 4: Authentication & Security
description: Protect your users and their data

lessons.title: 4.1 JWT & Bcrypt
lessons.content:
## 1. Password Hashing
NEVER store passwords as plain text. Use `bcrypt` to salt and hash them.

## 2. JWT (JSON Web Tokens)
A compact way to securely transmit information between parties as a JSON object. Used for maintaining user sessions without storing state on the server.

```javascript
const token = jwt.sign({ userId: user._id }, 'secret_key');
```
lessons.expectedOutput: A hashed password and a signed JWT.

quizQuestions.text: Why do we use 'salting' in cryptography?
quizQuestions.explanation: Salting adds random data to the input before hashing, ensuring that the same password results in a different hash every time.

lessons.title: 5.1 Controllers & Services
lessons.content:
Don't put all your logic in the route file! Use the **MVC (Model-View-Controller)** pattern.

## 1. Controller
Handles the request, calls the service, and sends a response.

## 2. Service
Contains the business logic (accessing DB, external APIs).

## 3. Global Error Handler
One place to handle all your API errors consistently.

quizQuestions.text: What is the primary role of a 'Controller' in a REST API?
quizQuestions.explanation: Controllers act as the entry point for requests, delegating logic to services and returning responses to the client.

title: LEVEL 6: Advanced React & State
description: Manage global state and optimize performance

lessons.title: 6.1 Redux Toolkit & Context API
lessons.content:
Passing data through 10 layers of components (prop drilling) is bad practice. Use a global state manager.

## 1. Context API
Built-in React feature for simple global data like themes or user profiles.

## 2. Redux Toolkit (RTK)
The industry standard for complex applications. It uses a **Single Source of Truth** (The Store).
lessons.expectedOutput: A centralized way to manage application-wide data.

options: Passing data through many components that don't need it
A way to connect to MongoDB
quizQuestions.explanation: Prop drilling occurs when you have to pass data through intermediate components just to reach a distant child.

title: LEVEL 7: Deployment & SaaS Patterns
description: Ship your app to production and scale it

lessons.title: 7.1 Vercel, Render & CI/CD
lessons.content:
## 1. Hosting Options
- **Frontend**: Vercel or Netlify (best for React).
- **Backend**: Render, Railway, or Heroku.
- **Database**: MongoDB Atlas or Supabase.

## 2. Environment Variables (.env)
NEVER commit API keys or database strings to GitHub. Use `.env` files and configure them in your hosting dashboard.

## 3. CI/CD
Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment. When you `git push`, the app builds and deploys automatically.
lessons.expectedOutput: A live website accessible to the world.

quizQuestions.text: Where should you store sensitive API keys in a production app?
options: In a .env file / Hosting platform secrets
quizQuestions.explanation: Environment variables are the secure way to manage configuration without exposing secrets in the codebase.

lessons.title: 8.1 Socket.io & Jest
lessons.content:
## 1. WebSockets (Socket.io)
Allows for bi-directional communication. Perfect for chat apps, notifications, and live dashboards.
`io.on('connection', (socket) => { ... });`

## 2. Testing with Jest
Automated tests ensure your code doesn't break when you make changes.
- **Unit Tests**: Test single functions.
- **Integration Tests**: Test how components work together.
lessons.expectedOutput: A passing test report indicating code safety.

options: WebSockets are bi-directional and always open
quizQuestions.explanation: HTTP is request-response based, while WebSockets allow the server to send data to the client at any time.

title: LEVEL 9: Final Fullstack Graduation
description: Prove your ability to build complete products

lessons.title: 9.1 The SaaS Architect Exam
lessons.content:
**Congratulations, Fullstack Developer!** You have mastered the entire stack, from database schemas to frontend animations.

## Final Evaluation:
- **Fullstack Logic**: Data flow between client and server.
- **Performance**: State management and API optimization.
- **Security**: Auth patterns and data protection.
- **DevOps**: Deployment strategies and observability.

## The Grand Prize:
- Complete this final module to unlock the **GenSpark Fullstack Hero Status** and showcase your portfolio piece to the world.
lessons.expectedOutput: A complete, functional dashboard connected to a live backend.

quizQuestions.text: Which part of the MERN stack is used for the backend framework?
quizQuestions.explanation: In MERN (MongoDB, Express, React, Node), Express is the framework that runs on Node.

quizQuestions.text: What is the purpose of 'middleware' in a backend application?
options: To run code between request and response
quizQuestions.explanation: Middleware functions run during the request-response cycle, allowing for logging, auth, and data parsing.

quizQuestions.text: What does 'React Query' (TanStack Query) primarily solve?
quizQuestions.explanation: React Query is used for fetching, caching, and synchronizing server state in React apps.

quizQuestions.text: True or False: MongoDB is a Relational Database.
quizQuestions.explanation: MongoDB is a NoSQL (Document-based) database, not relational (SQL).

quizQuestions.text: Which command starts the local development environment in most React/Node projects?
quizQuestions.explanation: npm run dev (or npm start) is the standard command defined in package.json for starting development servers.
